verdict.summary: The Laravel service container cannot resolve a binding because the target class doesn't exist, wasn't registered, or auto-discovery failed. Common after upgrading Laravel 8+ which removed default namespace prefix from RouteServiceProvider.

dead_ends.action: Adding the full namespace prefix back to RouteServiceProvider::$namespace
dead_ends.why_fails: Laravel 8+ intentionally removed the default namespace prefix to support PHP 8 named arguments and better IDE support. Re-adding it creates subtle routing issues with resource controllers and invokable controllers.

dead_ends.action: Running composer dump-autoload repeatedly without checking the actual class path
dead_ends.why_fails: dump-autoload regenerates the autoloader map, but if the class file doesn't exist or the namespace doesn't match the directory structure (PSR-4), re-dumping won't help.

workarounds.action: Use fully qualified class names in route definitions
workarounds.condition: Controllers not found after Laravel 8 upgrade

workarounds.action: Register the binding explicitly in a ServiceProvider
Clear all cached configs, routes, and services
workarounds.how: php artisan config:clear && php artisan route:clear && php artisan cache:clear && composer dump-autoload
workarounds.condition: After adding new provider or changing configuration

preceded_by.condition: Autoload misconfiguration causes class not found, leading to binding resolution failure

frequently_confused_with.distinction: BindingResolutionException is thrown by Laravel's DI container when resolving dependencies. Class not found (Error) is a PHP-level autoload failure. The former can occur even when the class exists if the container binding is misconfigured.
